reviewText:
There's a lot of things wrong with Running Shadow.

First, saying it's a mix of a runner and a fantasy RPG is...wrong. There's no RPG mechanics here, it's a runner, through and through. You run through various corridors picking up coins and mana. You can jump, slide, and do some silly looking special moves to dodge obstacles and traps. There are also enemies, but you fight them the same way: Press up or down depending on their stance to kill them.

You do missions to progress through the story, which involves some cult trying to use a magical gauntlet to resurrect the Old Gods. The story and characters are forgettable, and seems more like an afterthought. Which leaves the gameplay.

It plays mostly alright: 3 lane runner, controls seem to work fine. You earn in-game coins to upgrade your gear and access missions. It starts extremely easy, but after a while, the game's true form starts to show itself. After around 30 minutes, I could no longer kill enemies because I had to upgrade my weapon. Obstacles and enemies started doing around half my health in damage. The game started shoving DLC offers in my face for survival. Not because it'd make the game more fun or anything, just to PROGRESS.

I'd be happy to upgrade my equipment, but missions often require a coin fee to access, and I often find myself desperately short on cash. Eventually, about an hour in, enemies had the ability to one shot me, and obstacles almost did the same. I upgraded my sword, but I already couldn't kill these enemies either, having to upgrade more.

There are side missions you can do for coins, but the amount you earn is hilariously low. In addition, the difficulty isn't any easier in these side missions: You still can't kill most enemies, you'll still take huge amounts of damage, and you'll  maybe get 100 coins. Upgrades cost 2000-3000 early on, and new equipment generally starts at 5000. These side mission runs usually take 2 minutes a piece. Considering you survive.

Or, of course, you can buy the DLC. According to the DLC description, the outfits don't benefit your character at all, BUT you receive 10,000 coins. That's more than enough to make sure you have an easy time through most of the game. Don't worry, there's weapon and armor DLC too that does benefit your character.

Apparently there are special moves you can do, like draining health from enemies or instantly killing everything for a short period of time. I don't know how to get them to work. You use them specifically in training missions, but outside of that, I never had a chance to use them. Would've been nice, since they seem powerful, but that would prevent you from getting stuck and feeling forced to buy DLC just to progress.

It's pay to progress garbage. The game becomes either an extremely tedious and frustrating grind, or deceptively expensive if you want to see the awful story to the end. Avoid at all costs.

reviewText:
After putting in around 10 hours of actual gameplay, discounting some AFK time, I think I can share my (many, probably too many) thoughts.

My first thought is that this brings me back to the chaos emerald stages of Sonic 2 (and to a lesser extent, Sonic 3), Being a huge fan of those old Sonic games, this genre hits a sweet spot for me. The game is a grind. You will be doing the same things over and over again at various levels of difficulty. To call this game bad because because of this is like calling One Finger Death Punch or Space Invaders or bowling bad because of it. It makes no sense if you are actually having fun with the gameplay.

Anyway, about the actual game:

Pros
It's a casual game designed to be rather addictive. In my opinion it is as such.
Controls feel (minus a few bugs. see Cons) very responsive. It can get pretty fast-paced, but you still feel in control.
It looks fine. Different areas are colorful and stuff. Environments are not terribly different, but enough to mix things up a little.
Satisfying to master. Started off dying quite a bit and using lot of the buff things, but now I always play natty and die a whole lot less, usually to bugs or really unfortunate combos of obstacles.
Cons
There are bugs. Sometimes the buttons don't work for killing the QTE enemies. Sometimes the buttons (1,2,3,4) are out of order, which is kinda weird and can throw you off. Rarely I've seen objects spawned way up in the air and unreachable. Others have seen bugs that I haven't seen, so I can't really comment on that.
Some obstacles are near impossible to see at times, especially when other things wreck your line of sight.
As far as I know you can't remap buttons, which would be convenient especially for the QTEs.
To start the games, you have to click buttons. It's a minor thing, but it would be way more convenient to have keyboard bindings for that since the VAST majority of gameplay is 1 handed.
General Thoughts
Personally, I like it. I don't think it's for everyone.

Obviously it is FTP with micro-transactions, so there's gating and the gold cost of upgrades is higher than seems necessary. However, I don't think it's quite as bad as people tend to make it. At the stage of the game I'm at, a run will net me 400-ish gold, a little less if I suck. Gates and upgrades are 5500 -8000 or so. It could be a lot worse. I play it for the gameplay because I enjoy mindlessly reflexing some dude to flip and slide around with decent visuals whilst listening to trap music (Should be the official soundtrack, but I sadly don't make these decisions).

The story and rpg elements are really only there to give a sense of purpose, but none of it is that important or engaging. Gear is used as another way to gate, so most of the time you're not even choosing what to upgrade. A lot of quests are along the lines of: Go get this ring. Neat! Now get this necklace. Neat! This game is a lot better than I expected. It's a shallow runner game and obviously a mobile port. The graphics are nice and the game is well made. It's obviously not a AAA title, but it's better than most of the greenlight and early access titles covering steam. I saw the reviews coming in, and was expecting to hit a gold wall where the f2p systems became abusive. I haven't found that yet after 4 hours, and that's longer than any of the negative reviews I've seen of the game. If you like runners, it's actually a nice little game to kill some time in. I'm sure most people looking at reviews are going to see if the game is abusively F2P, so let me explain where that notion might come from.

Potential Gold Pressure 1- Map Unlocks:
New map locations are unlocked with gold. You get missions at these locations with random requirements (collect mana, find items, kill baddies), and each location has a different look and usually some unique mechanics. Rooftops have multi-leveled running, the dungeon has more pits and floor traps, a temple has pillars that burst through the ground as you get close, etc. The main story will eventually drag you through these places, and at some points the story might move you to a new location before you have the gold on hand. This happens once about 2 hours in, where you need 3000 gold to continue and have about 1500. This is the 'paywall' people are talking about.

Why it isn't bad:
The map locations level up as you play non-story levesls on them. They have difficulty ranks, and end up giving higher and higher payouts. New mechanics from later levels show up in even the first levels at higher difficulty, keeping them interesting. You can get 500 gold payouts on expert level missions, making that 1500 gold seem like nothing. The game isn't making you grind boring, slow, easy levels just to get anywhere fun. The game is a runner, and running an old map at a higher difficulty is still fun for me.

reviewText:
This is very similar to Temple Run for mobile devices. However, it has a slightly more in depth RPG element to it, with customisable outfits, and upgradable weapons. I recommend this for people who don't have the time to play an in depth RPG.

After playing for an extended amount of time (Over two hours straight), I am still enjoying this game. Why? Because I'm playing it for what it is. Do I expect an immersive RPG experience? No, I do not. Do I expect tension filled moments of dashing through narrow corridors, while barely escaping traps at the last moment? Yes.

I will admit, I was pleasantly surprised with what I got. Yes, it was a very Temple Runish game at first. However, the first few minutes of gameplay do NOT in any way compare to the overall experience. There is some sort of strange satisfaction in leaping over a flaming trap, only to meat a hostile spearman waiting to challenge you. And after you've completely brutalised him, you narrowly evade a blade shooting from the wall to slice you in half, kicking a heavily armoured enemy in the chest and bringing your sword down to stab him in the torso.

Running Shadow is a thrilling, innovative experience, bringing a new style to the genre.

reviewText:
As you can see, I have played this game for a good couple of hours. Short version of this review: I personally like it. Now for the longer version.

The game is about a thief who gets his hands on an awesome gauntlet that gives him magic power and then goes on to learn awesome thief things. Or something. Yeah, the story didn't really grab me, but considering the amount of dialogues in the game, it definitely is there. I can't really fairly comment on it, since I skipped through most of in favour of actually playing.

The gameplay consists of you controlling a running thief. You can move him left and right and you can jump and slide. Every level consists of reaching a certain goal such as breaking x number of barrels or killing a certain amount of enemies. There's not much more to it than that.

As for the music and graphics, I quite liked them. The character designs are detailed and the levels themselves look quite nice. The music consists of just a couple of tracks, but for me it took a while before they became a bit stale. Nothing mind blowing, not bad either.

Now, I've seen there are quite a couple of people complaining about the fact that this is a port of a mobile game. In my eyes, that would only be a problem if the port was buggy and the controls unintuitive. While I did run across some minor bugs, the game does run smoothly. As for the DLC, yes, it is there, but it is by no means a necessity.

I understand that this game will not be for everyone, but then again that holds true for pretty much anything. If you like simple games that are free to play, I can definitely recommend this. I admit I'm easily entertained, though. If you dislike the running game genre or want deep story and gameplay, I'd say you might want to pass this.

reviewText:
Disclaimer:   The following review is valid as of the March 5, 2015 update.  It's entirely possible that further releases will add new content, or change the pros and/or remedy the cons addressed below. While I will try to update my review as needed, it's also entirely possible that I won't come back to it. As always, use your best judgment when making purchases.

Running Shadow is a 3D runner game with bare bones character action trappings.

On one hand, this is a fun addition to the genre, and the side missions ramp up in difficulty fast if you're itching for a challenge. There are a number of mission types, but they typically boil down to the same goal: avoid obstacles, collect coin, and take out enemies until the exit is reached.

A chunk of the game is devoted to the “RPG” elements, which play out in a manner similar to those found in character action games. Coin received on missions, based on your relative success at the level, goes toward gear upgrades, consumables, and skill acquisition. In addition, feats and kills play out in a manner reminiscent of simplified character action, in which a button or button combination is pressed, and the animation plays out.

The artwork is delightful, with trinkets, characters, and the world map looking sleek and polished. The graphics, while not terrible, are obviously designed with less powerful machines in mind. Occasionally levels will open up, and switch over into a 2.5D perspective, thus changing up the gameplay somewhat. The level design is minimal in terms of assets, with each area having its own standard set. This is made up for by the fact that levels are randomized, thus remixing the level and obstacles each time that area is played.

The microtransactions aren't obtrusive or particularly necessary. They're largely cosmetic or convenience features, and can easily be avoided unless you'd like to support the devs.

The sound design is, as a whole, neither bad or particularly great. The music is no exception; it likely won't grate on your nerves, but it isn't particularly amazing, either.

On the other hand, the story is stilted at best, and laughable at worst. The handful of two-dimensional characters deliver some very awkward disposition before each mission in the interest of relating the story. In particular, the way the hero is regarded by the other characters smacks of poor fan fiction.

You're booted out of the mission each time you fail, and focus is pulled to the part of the map where the main mission is located. This is inconvenient and short-sighted, considering the meat of the game appears to be grinding the side missions to upgrade equipment; an action that will require multiple restarts of missions from all but the most skilled of players.

Finally, and perhaps more a nitpick than a real critique, is that it's a shame that the collections acquired throughout the levels serve no other purpose than to confer sporadic consumable rewards. Some of them look interesting enough to be made into gear/cosmetic features for the player, but aren't.

All told, I recommend this game, with a caveat: you'll likely enjoy this best if you're really into the runner genre. It's certainly fun in that respect, and will offer a fair bit of challenge and game time. That said, if you're not a fan, or were hoping for a more in-depth RPG system, you'll likely find this title lacking.

reviewText:
Recommended up until 5 hours or so.

I was pleasantly surprised by this game.  It's pretty good quality and seems like a game for tablet, but I don't mind good quality tablet games on steam. It's quite fun and a good test of reflex. Firstly, it is pay to win, but I wouldn't say you need to pay to have fun. In fact, paying would probably make it boring. Paying just lets you take a few hits, but there's nothing stopping you from playing for free and using quick reflexes to beat missions without getting hit.

I enjoy the story, and the items are a cool idea. That said, at level 12 I realized that they completely ARBITRARILY make you buy an expensive, unnecessary item. It had done this previously but previously I had enough money to proceed whereas this time I didn't. These items increase your survivability but are not needed. What this meant is that although I was doing well, I essentially got stopped and had to grind for no reason. I then had to raise 4500 gold in increments of 100-200 per run. I couldn't even do side missions since my storyline and 2 side missions all took place in the same location and the gear check was locking me out of that place.

The only other issue was sometimes the buttons aren't quite responsive when fighting nephalim. This seems to get worse the further into the game you get. I've died quite a few times hitting the button shown on screen and nothing happens. Unlike other reviews, I never had a single issue with hit detection.

Overall, it's free and quite fun up until the grind at 5 hours. I'm going to keep playing, but if I run into another arbitrary gear check, I'll probably quit. 5 hours of fun for free isn't bad though.

Edit: 9 hours in and I'd say it's downhill from 5 hours. The game gets grindy and way too easy once you've figured everything out.

Edit2: 12 hours in and it's even more downhill. Nothing new since the 5 hour mark. It's clear the developers only put effort into the first part of the game. It's now so easy I'm starting to watch tv while I play. The story is super repetitive: get a disguise kill boss, repeat. Level 16 slams 24,000 gold worth of arbitrary barriers in front of you that you have to grind 100-200 gold at a time. I'm finished.
